full_address: Šķūņu iela 17, Centra rajons, Rīga, LV-1050
notes_eng: Hollander's houses at Šķūņu iela 17/19. Oval Hall in the Hollander's house at Šķūņu iela 17/19 (1787). Several luxurious interiors, doors, and ceiling paintings from the Classicism era are still visible in the buildings. The oval dining hall on the second floor was restored in 1959 and again from 1975 to 1977. The buildings now house shops, a library, and offices.
source: Jānis Krastiņš, Rīgas arhitektūras stili (Rīga: Jumava, 2005), 65.
author: Vladislavs Babaņins

full_address: Hanzas iela, Centra rajons, Rīga, LV-1010
architect_all_eng: Built under the supervision of Johann Daniel Gottfried but the author of the project unknown
notes_eng: Initially, the gate was located at the Riga city border on the Petersburg Road, approximately where the Gaisa Bridge on Brīvības Street is now. In 1904, it was moved further—around Šmerlis Street—but in 1936, it was relocated to its current location.
source: Jānis Krastiņš, Rīgas arhitektūras stili (Rīga: Jumava, 2005), 72.
author: Vladislavs Babaņins

notes_eng: * An eclectic building designed in the expression of Classicism. The architectural scholar, Professor Jānis Krastiņš, has expressed the view that the building’s style can also be described as very late Classicism.

full_address: Hospitāļu iela 55, Vidzemes priekšpilsēta, Rīga, LV-1013
architect_all_eng: Fjodors Demercovs, Aleksandrs Štauberts, Johans Eduards de Vite
notes_eng: It is the oldest masonry building in today’s central part of Riga outside the Old Town, as the territory of the former suburbs allowed only wooden buildings to be constructed until 1858. The hospital is located far enough from Vecrīga (the Inner City), beyond the boundaries of the then masonry-building prohibition.
source: Jānis Krastiņš, Rīgas arhitektūras stili (Rīga: Jumava, 2005), 76.

full_address: Rātslaukums 1, Centra rajons, Rīga, LV-1050
notes_eng: Riga Town Hall /Johann von Ettinger/ (1765–1954) – the original building was demolished. A high mansard roof was added in 1793. The mansard roof was replaced by a full third floor by Johann Daniel Felsko in 1848. The building burned down during World War II and was demolished in 1954. A Riga Technical University laboratory building was constructed on the site in 1964, which was later demolished to make space for the new Town Hall, completed in 2001.
source: Jānis Krastiņš, Rīgas arhitektūras stili (Rīga: Jumava, 2005), 65.
author: Vladislavs Babaņins

full_address: Torņa iela 1, Centra rajons, Rīga, LV-1050
architect_all_eng: Johann Eduard de Witte (originally), Giovanni (Ivan) Francevich Lucchini, Alexander Nellinger, Julius Adolf Spatzier
notes_eng: Since 1987, the building has been converted into an art museum. It also houses the Goethe-Institut Riga.
source: Jānis Krastiņš, Rīgas arhitektūras stili (Rīga: Jumava, 2005), 76.
author: Vladislavs Babaņins
